questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department in a disoriented state. He lives alone, has poor nutrition, and consumes large amounts of alcohol. On examination, he appears emaciated, with abdominal distension, jaundice, ascites, and mild hepatosplenomegaly. A liver biopsy was done and is seen in the image. Which blood test would best confirm a diagnosis of hepatic coma?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical picture and biopsy, showing parenchymal nodules surrounded by fibrosis, indicate cirrhosis with hepatic encephalopathy, also called hepatic coma, which presents as confusion, stupor, or coma.
  • Ammonia is the key neurotoxin implicated in hepatic encephalopathy. It is produced in the gut and normally detoxified in the liver via the urea cycle.
  • In cirrhosis, detoxification fails, leading to elevated serum ammonia, which impairs neuronal function and causes cerebral oedema (via conversion to glutamine in astrocytes).

Explanation of other options:

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) (Option A): ALT is a marker of hepatocellular injury, but its levels do not correlate with hepatic encephalopathy. ALT may be normal or only mildly elevated in chronic cirrhosis.

Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) (Option B): ALP is elevated in cholestasis or bile duct obstruction, but it is not related to encephalopathy or mental status changes.

Bilirubin (Option D): Bilirubin reflects liver excretory function and can be elevated in many liver diseases, including cirrhosis, but it does not cause encephalopathy. It may contribute to jaundice but not cognitive impairment.

choices.text: Centrilobular zone is around hepatic vein

questions.text: A microscopic H&E-stained slide of normal liver histology is shown. Which of the following statements regarding liver zonation based on blood supply is/are correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This acinar model divides hepatocytes into 3 zones based on proximity to the portal tract (oxygen source):
  • Zone 1: Periportal zone
    • Closest to the portal tract.
    • Receives the most oxygenated blood.
    • Rich in enzymes for oxidative metabolism, gluconeogenesis, and the urea cycle.
    • First to be affected by blood-borne toxins.
    • Most resilient to hypoxia.
  • Zone 2: Intermediate zone
    • Transitional area between Zones 1 and 3.
  • Zone 3: Centrilobular zone
    • Closest to the central vein.
    • Receives the least oxygenated blood.
    • Functions in anaerobic metabolism, drug detoxification (cytochrome P450), and lipogenesis.
    • Most vulnerable to hypoxia, congestive heart failure, and drug-induced injury (e.g., acetaminophen toxicity).
    • Site of centrilobular necrosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient went for a preanesthetic checkup before laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He was found to be positive for viral hepatitis by the ELISA method. After an appointment with a gastroenterologist, liver biopsy was performed and is as shown below shown below. Based on the above features, identify a possible etiological agent.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The liver biopsy in this case shows lymphoid follicles, portal lymphocytic infiltrates, and interface hepatitis-hallmark features of chronic hepatitis C infection.

Hepatitis C Virus (HCV):

The Virus

  • HCV is a small, enveloped, single-stranded RNA virus from the Flaviviridae
  • High mutation rate allows frequent immune escape, contributing to persistent infection.

Epidemiology

  • Infects ~170 million people worldwide.
  • Major transmission: IV drug use, transfusion, unsafe healthcare practices.
  • Rarely causes symptomatic acute hepatitis, but it is the leading cause of chronic viral hepatitis.

Clinical Course

  • Most acute infections are asymptomatic.
  • 85-90% progress to chronic hepatitis.
  • Chronic HCV can cause cirrhosis, liver failure, and hepatocellular carcinoma over decades.

Treatment

  • Modern direct-acting antivirals (DAAs) target NS3/NS5A/NS5B proteins.
  • High cure rates with early detection and full antiviral course.

Explanation for the answer:

HAV (Hepatitis A Virus) (Option A): A non-enveloped RNA virus transmitted via the faecal-oral route. It does not cause chronic hepatitis. Liver biopsy typically shows a "spotty lobular" inflammation with mononuclear infiltrates, not portal lymphoid follicles.

HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) (Option B): A DNA virus transmitted via blood, sexual contact, or perinatal exposure. Biopsy shows "ground-glass hepatocytes" due to HBsAg accumulation and interface hepatitis, but without lymphoid follicles in portal tracts.

HEV (Hepatitis E Virus) (Option D): A non-enveloped RNA virus also transmitted by the faecal-oral route, especially via contaminated water. Like HAV, it does not lead to chronic infection in immunocompetent patients (but may in pregnant or immunocompromised individuals). Histology resembles acute hepatitis, not the chronic features seen in HCV.

questions.text: The characteristic feature of 'Ground glass' appearance, as shown in the figure below, is seen in:-
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ground-glass hepatocytes in chronic hepatitis B are caused by the accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen.
  • Haematoxylin-eosin staining shows the presence of abundant, finely granular pink cytoplasmic inclusions; immunostaining (inset) with a specific antibody confirms the presence of surface antigen (brown).
  • 'Ground-glass' hepatocytes are liver cells that have eosinophilic granular, glassy cytoplasm on light microscopy.
  • This appearance corresponds to a proliferated smooth endoplasmic reticulum ultrastructure.
  • These changes may be drug-induced or associated with hepatitis B antigenaemia, particularly in carriers.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatitis A (Option A): Does not produce ground-glass cells; shows acute lobular hepatitis with apoptotic hepatocytes.

Hepatitis C (Option C): Associated with fatty change and lymphoid aggregates in portal tracts, not ground-glass hepatocytes.

Hepatitis D (Option D): Requires co-infection/superinfection with Hepatitis B but does not independently cause ground-glass hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman presents with abdominal pain and recurrent vomiting. Ultrasound reveals gallstones, and she is scheduled for cholecystectomy. Preanesthetic checkup shows HBsAg positivity (4.42 IU by ELISA) and presence of HBeAg. If a liver biopsy were performed at this stage, which of the following findings would most likely not be seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ground-glass hepatocytes are a hallmark of chronic HBV infection during the inactive carrier or immune-inactive phase, not typically seen during active viral replication with HBeAg positivity.
  • This patient has active replication of HBV (indicated by HBeAg positivity).
  • Liver biopsy in the early immune-tolerant or immune-active phase typically shows:
    • Portal and lobular inflammation (due to immune cell infiltration).
    • Hepatocyte necrosis or apoptosis (ranging from spotty to bridging necrosis).

Explanation of other options:

Portal inflammation (Option A): Seen in HBV infection, especially during the immune-active phase. Inflammatory infiltrates (mostly lymphocytes) are present in portal tracts and are a hallmark of ongoing immune response to infected hepatocytes.

Lobular inflammation (Option B): Also common in active hepatitis B. Inflammatory cells may spill into the lobules, leading to spotty necrosis of hepatocytes.

Hepatocyte necrosis (Option D): Can be focal or confluent, depending on severity. May progress to bridging necrosis, connecting portal tracts to central veins. Hepatocyte apoptosis and necrosis are part of immune-mediated liver injury.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male patient presents with complaints of nausea, easy fatigability, and yellowish discolouration of the sclera. He reports chronic, heavy alcohol consumption. On clinical evaluation, his serum bilirubin level is found to be elevated. A liver biopsy is performed. Which of the following histological features is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic heavy alcohol use + jaundice + raised bilirubin point toward alcoholic liver injury.
  • Liver biopsy confirms alcoholic hepatitis, and classic histological features include:
  • Ballooned Hepatocytes:
    • Enlarged hepatocytes with pale, cleared cytoplasm due to cytoskeletal damage.
    • Often contain Mallory hyaline-pink, ropey cytoplasmic inclusions made of damaged cytokeratin filaments.
  • Mallory Hyaline Bodies:
    • Found in ballooned hepatocytes.
    • Indicative of hepatocyte injury and failed attempts at protein degradation.
  • Lobular and Portal Inflammation:
    • Mainly neutrophilic infiltration, especially near damaged hepatocytes and Mallory bodies.
    • It may also have lymphocytes.
  • Perivenular/Pericellular Fibrosis:
    • 'Chicken wire'appearance.
    • Often begins around the central vein (Zone 3) and may progress to cirrhosis.

choices.text: Anti-soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas antigen antibodies (anti- SLA/LP)

questions.text: All of the following autoantibodies are seen in Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Anti-LKM-1 antibodies are not seen in Type 1.
  • Instead, they are the defining autoantibody in Type 2 autoimmune hepatitis, which is more common in children.
  • These antibodies are directed against CYP2D6.
  • Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis is the more common form, typically affecting adults, and shows a strong female predominance.
  • It is characterised by the presence of ANA, anti-smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies, and anti-SLA/LP antibodies.
  • The diagnosis is based on autoantibodies, raised IgG levels, histology, and exclusion of other causes like viral hepatitis or drug injury.

Explanation of other options:

Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) (Option A): Commonly found in Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis and help support the diagnosis.

Anti-soluble liver antigen/liver-pancreas (anti-SLA/LP) antibodies (Option B): Also seen in Type 1 and considered highly specific.

Anti-smooth muscle actin (SMA) antibodies (Option D): Another hallmark antibody of Type 1 autoimmune hepatitis.

Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In hepatitis B, 'ground-glass'hepatocytes are seen.
Reason (R): In hepatitis B, the endoplasmic reticulum is swollen by HBsAg.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Statement A: True

  • 'Ground-glass' hepatocytes are seen in chronic hepatitis B.
  • On light microscopy, these hepatocytes appear pale, granular, and glassy due to the accumulation of viral proteins.

Statement R: True and causally related

  • The smooth endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in hepatocytes becomes swollen with hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg).
  • This intracellular accumulation of HBsAg within the ER is what gives the hepatocytes their characteristic'ground-glass' appearance.

questions.text: An infant girl presents with prolonged jaundice. A liver biopsy is performed, and the findings are as shown. What is the most likely composition of the globules seen?
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

  • The presence of eosinophilic intracytoplasmic globules in hepatocytes in a neonate with jaundice is characteristic of alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  • These globules are composed of misfolded AAT protein retained within the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes.
  • They are PAS-positive and diastase-resistant, and immunoreactive for AAT.
  • Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency: AAT deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in the SERPINA1 gene, leading to low circulating levels of α -antitrypsin, a protease inhibitor that protects tissues from neutrophil elastase.

Pathogenesis:

  • The Z allele produces misfolded AAT proteins that accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes.
  • This results in a toxic gain of function in the liver (due to retained globules) and a loss of function in the lungs (due to lack of circulating AAT).

Histology:

  • Characteristic round-to-oval eosinophilic cytoplasmic globules in periportal hepatocytes.
  • PAS-positive, diastase-resistant (PASD+).
  • Confirmed by immunostaining for AAT.
  • Seen in both infants (cholestasis, neonatal hepatitis) and adults (chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis).

Clinical relevance:

  • In infants: Prolonged jaundice, hepatitis.
  • In adults: Risk of cirrhosis and panacinar emphysema (especially in non-smokers with early-onset COPD).

Explanation of other options:

Fibrinogen (Option B): Can accumulate in fibrinogen storage disease, but this is extremely rare and not typically seen in neonatal jaundice.

Glycogen (Option C): Found in disorders like Glycogen storage diseases, and would be PAS-positive but diastase-sensitive, unlike AAT globules.

Mucin (Option D): Found in epithelial mucinous tumours and mucosal glands, not in hepatocyte cytoplasm.

questions.text: The phenomenon of quasi-species is most characteristically seen in which type of viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • HCV is an ssRNA virus from the Flaviviridae family with an error-prone RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (NS5B).
  • This enzyme lacks proofreading ability, leading to frequent replication errors.
  • As a result, genetically related but distinct viral variants accumulate and co-exist within a single host-a phenomenon called quasi-species.
  • These evolving variants help the virus evade neutralising antibodies, especially those directed against the E2 envelope protein.
  • The NS3/NS4A protease further disrupts host defence by impairing interferon signalling, promoting persistent infection.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatitis A (Option A): An ssRNA virus from the Picornavirus family with high genetic stability. It does not exhibit quasi-species behaviour.

Hepatitis B (Option B): A partially double-stranded DNA virus (Hepadnavirus). DNA viruses have higher replication fidelity and do not generate quasi-species in the same way RNA viruses do.

Hepatitis D (Option D): A defective circular ssRNA virus that depends on HBV for replication. It does not undergo significant quasi-species diversification independently.

questions.text: All of the following hepatitis viruses are RNA viruses except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is the only DNA virus among the major hepatitis viruses.
  • It has a partially double-stranded DNA genome (diDNA), belonging to the Hepadnavirus family.
  • All other hepatitis viruses (A, C, D, E) are RNA viruses. (Options A, C and D ruled out)

questions.text: A roadside beggar is admitted to the medicine ward with a diagnosis of cirrhosis of the liver. On clinical examination, he shows signs such as palmar erythema and spider angiomas. Hormonal investigations are sent to a specialised laboratory. Which of the following altered hormonal profiles is most commonly seen in such patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In chronic liver failure, the liver loses its ability to metabolise estrogens efficiently, leading to hyperestrogenemia.
  • This results in several characteristic clinical findings:
    • Palmar erythema (due to local vasodilation)
    • Spider angiomas (central pulsatile arteriole with radiating vessels)
    • Gynecomastia and hypogonadism in males
  • These changes occur because:
    • The liver normally inactivates circulating estrogens.
    • In cirrhosis, impaired hepatic metabolism → estrogen accumulation → systemic vascular and endocrine effects.
  • Renal clearance plays a minor role in estrogen elimination and is not primarily responsible for hormonal imbalance in cirrhosis.

Explanation of other options:

Hypoestrogenemia - impaired metabolism (Option B): Cirrhosis leads to impaired metabolism of estrogens, but instead of lowering levels, this results in estrogen accumulation, i.e., hyperestrogenemia. The liver is the major site of estrogen inactivation; when it fails, levels rise, not fall.

Hyperestrogenemia - impaired renal clearance (Option C): Estrogens are metabolised by the liver, not primarily excreted by the kidneys. Renal clearance plays a minor role in estrogen elimination. In liver failure, the cause of increased estrogen is impaired hepatic metabolism, not renal dysfunction.

Hypoestrogenemia - impaired renal clearance (Option D): Hypoestrogenemia is not seen in cirrhosis (it's hyperestrogenemia). Estrogen clearance is not primarily renal.

questions.text: Which is the first site of scar deposition in liver biopsy under the microscope?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The principal cell responsible for scar formation in the liver is the hepatic stellate cell, located in the space of Disse.
  • In the normal (quiescent) state, stellate cells store vitamin A and lipids.
  • Upon chronic injury, these cells get activated by:
    • Inflammatory cytokines (e.g., TNF-α from Kupffer cells and macrophages)
    • Toxins and reactive oxygen species (ROS)
    • Altered ECM interactions
  • Activated stellate cells differentiate into myofibroblasts, which secrete collagen and other matrix proteins.
  • Scar deposition begins in the space of Disse, accompanied by:
    • Loss of sinusoidal fenestrations ("sinusoidal capillarization")
    • Disruption of microcirculation
  • With persistent injury, fibrosis may extend to portal tracts, central veins, and eventually form bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis.

Explanation of other options:

Portal triad (Option A): Involved later as fibrosis progresses; not the initial site.

Between bile canaliculi (Option B): No recognised role in fibrosis initiation.

Around the central vein (Option C): May show pericentral fibrosis in some specific conditions (e.g., alcohol-related liver disease), but not the universal first site.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents with abdominal pain for a few days. Vitals: Temp 98.7F, HR 101 bpm, RR 19/min, BP 129/82 mmHg. On examination, he has a tender, enlarged liver. Labs show AST: 271 U/L, ALT: 46 U/L, GGT: 190 U/L, Alkaline phosphatase: 210 U/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • AST: ALT ratio > 2:1 is characteristic of alcoholic liver injury. Here, the ratio is approximately 6:1.
  • Clinical signs: Hepatomegaly and tenderness are common in alcoholic hepatitis.
  • Supporting labs: Elevated GGT and alkaline phosphatase are also consistent with chronic alcohol use.
  • Alcoholic hepatitis is an inflammatory liver disease caused by prolonged and excessive alcohol consumption.
  • It typically represents the middle phase of the spectrum of alcoholic liver disease (ALD), which progresses from:
  • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver)→ Alcoholic hepatitis→ Cirrhosis

Pathogenesis

Several mechanisms contribute to liver injury in alcoholic hepatitis:

  1. Toxic Metabolites: Alcohol is metabolised to acetaldehyde, which forms adducts with proteins (e.g., acetaldehyde-protein adducts), triggers lipid peroxidation, and disrupts cytoskeletal and membrane function
  2. Oxidative Stress: Alcohol increases CYP2E1 enzyme activity → generates ROS (reactive oxygen species) → causes mitochondrial dysfunction and promotes apoptosis
  3. Metabolic Derangements: NAD+is depleted → inhibits fatty acid oxidation → increases peripheral fat mobilisation → leads to macrovesicular steatosis. Impairs lipoprotein secretion → lipid accumulation in hepatocytes
  4. Immune & Inflammatory Activation: Alcohol increases gut permeability → lipopolysaccharide (LPS) enters portal blood → LPS binds to CD14 on Kupffer cells → activates TLR4 → cytokine storm → Triggers hepatocellular inflammation and fibrosis
  5. Gender & Genetic Factors: Women are more susceptible (due to estrogen effects on endotoxin sensitivity). Genetic variants like ALDH2 deficiency (common in Asians) worsen toxicity

Morphology (Microscopy & Gross Pathology)

  • Steatosis: Predominantly macrovesicular (large fat vacuoles), often centrilobular
  • Inflammation: Neutrophil-rich inflammation often surrounds ballooned hepatocytes
  • Ballooned Hepatocytes: Swollen cells with rarefied cytoplasm, contain Mallory-Denk bodies (clumped intermediate filaments)
  • Fibrosis: Begins pericentrally or perisinusoidally ('chicken-wire fibrosis'), progresses to bridging fibrosis and cirrhosis
  • Cirrhosis (Advanced Stage): Nodular liver with regenerative nodules, may present de novo without prior hepatitis or steatosis

Explanation of other options:

Viral hepatitis (Option A): ALT is typically higher than AST, often with both values >500 U/L; not seen here.

Acetaminophen toxicity (Option C): Typically causes massive transaminase elevation (often >1000 U/L); also, ALT would exceed AST.

Acute cholecystitis (Option D): Typically presents with right upper quadrant pain, Murphy's sign, and signs of gallbladder inflammation, not liver enzyme derangement with high AST: ALT.

questions.text: A 36-year-old alcoholic woman presents with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae. She has suffered from persistent headaches. Her vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals jaundice. Laboratory studies disclose markedly elevated levels of AST and ALT (956 and 1,400 U/L, respectively). A few days later, she develops hepatic encephalopathy and renal failure. A liver biopsy shows prominent centrilobular necrosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Chronic alcohol use induces CYP2E1, which increases the formation of toxic metabolites from acetaminophen.
  • The patient presents with acute liver failure, marked by sudden jaundice, very high AST/ALT, followed by hepatic encephalopathy and renal failure.
  • Liver biopsy shows classic centrilobular (zone 3) necrosis, characteristic of acetaminophen toxicity.

Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI):

  • Causes: Medications, herbal products, poisons (e.g., Amanita mushrooms), industrial chemicals.

Mechanisms of Injury:

  1. Direct (Intrinsic) Hepatotoxicity
    • Predictable & dose-dependent
    • Classic example: Acetaminophen (NAPQI metabolite)
    • Affects centrilobular zone (Zone 3) → necrosis
  2. Idiosyncratic Reactions
    • Unpredictable, not dose-related
    • Occurs in genetically susceptible individuals (e.g., NAT2 variant with isoniazid)

Metabolism Factors

  • Most drug injury is via CYP450 metabolism, especially CYP2E1
  • CYP inducers like alcohol, rifampin, and phenytoin increase toxicity
  • Zone 3 (centrilobular) hepatocytes have the highest CYP activity → most affected

Morphologic Patterns

  • Hepatocellular injury (most common): acute hepatitis-like, necrosis, inflammation
  • Cholestatic pattern: bile duct damage, duct dropout
  • Mixed injury: both elevated ALT and ALP
  • Other patterns:
    • Steatohepatitis (e.g., amiodarone, methotrexate)
    • Microvesicular steatosis (e.g., valproic acid, tetracycline)
    • Sinusoidal obstruction syndrome (e.g., oxaliplatin)

Clinical Features

  • Highly variable presentation: mimics viral, autoimmune, or metabolic hepatitis
  • Diagnosis by temporal link to drug, exclusion of other causes, and recovery on withdrawal
  • Rechallenge is rarely done due to risk

Explanation of other options:

Fatty Liver of Pregnancy (Option B): Occurs in the late third trimester, associated with microvesicular steatosis, not centrilobular necrosis. Presents with nausea, vomiting, and liver dysfunction in pregnant women.

Metastatic Carcinoma (Option C): Usually causes mass lesions or chronic liver dysfunction, not acute necrosis or high AST/ALT in thousands.

Reye Syndrome (Option D): Affects children, often after viral illness + aspirin use; shows microvesicular steatosis of the liver and cerebral oedema.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male is evaluated for persistently elevated AST (72 U/L) and ALT (73 U/L), which remained high after one month. Creatine kinase is normal (44 U/L). Tests for anti-HCV, HBsAg, and serum protein electrophoresis are normal. Liver ultrasound is unremarkable. Serum ceruloplasmin is 17 mg/dL, and serum copper is 57 μg/dL. He is not on medications and drinks 1-2 beers per week. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Persistently elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT) in a young adult with no viral or autoimmune markers and normal muscle enzymes suggest a metabolic liver disorder.
  • Low ceruloplasmin (17 mg/dL) and low serum copper (57 μg/dL) are classic for Wilson's disease.
  • Normal ultrasound and absence of other systemic findings help rule out structural or inflammatory causes.

Wilson's Disease:

  • Cause: Autosomal recessive disorder due to ATP7B gene mutation → impaired copper excretion into bile and failure to bind copper to ceruloplasmin.
  • Pathology: Copper accumulates in the liver, brain, and eyes, leading to hepatic injury, neurologic symptoms, and Kayser-Fleischer rings.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Onset: 6-40 years
    • Symptoms: Hepatitis, neuropsychiatric issues, cirrhosis, hemolytic anaemia
  • Diagnosis: ↓ Ceruloplasmin, ↑ urinary copper, and slit-lamp exam for KF rings
  • Treatment: Chelators (penicillamine/trientine), zinc, and liver transplant if needed

Explanation of other options:

Autoimmune hepatitis (Option A): Would usually show elevated IgG and positive autoantibodies (e.g., ANA, SMA)

α-1-antitrypsin deficiency (Option B): Often presents earlier or later with lung and liver disease, and diagnosis involves AAT levels and genotyping.

Menkes disease (Option C): X-linked disorder of copper transport, presents in infancy with neurodegeneration, kinky hair, and failure to thrive, not isolated liver enzyme elevation in adults.

questions.text: A 37-year-old white female presents with fatigue, malaise, abdominal pain, and new-onset jaundice. She has a history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Examination reveals mild hepatomegaly and scleral icterus. Labs show ALT: 430 U/L, AST: 389 U/L, Total bilirubin: 6.7 mg/dL, Direct bilirubin: 2.3 mg/dL and Serum IgG: 2,130 mg/dL. She denies alcohol or IV drug use. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The markedly elevated ALT and AST levels, along with significantly raised IgG, point toward an immune-mediated liver injury.
  • The patient's history of Hashimoto's thyroiditis supports an underlying autoimmune predisposition.
  • Absence of alcohol or IV drug use further excludes other common causes, making autoimmune hepatitis the most likely diagnosis.

Autoimmune Hepatitis:

  • Chronic inflammatory liver disease of unknown cause, likely autoimmune.
  • Most common in young to middle-aged women.
  • Characterised by:
    • Elevated ALT > AST.
    • High serum IgG.
    • Positive ANA, SMA, or anti-LKM1 antibodies (not given in question, but diagnostic).
  • Associated with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., thyroiditis, type 1 DM).
  • Histology: Interface hepatitis with lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates.
  • Treatment: Responds well to corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone).

Explanation of other options:

Alcoholic hepatitis (Option A): Typically shows AST > ALT, both < 300 U/L; patient denies alcohol use.

Primary biliary cholangitis (PBC) (Option B): Also affects middle-aged women. More cholestatic pattern (↑ ALP, ↑ GGT). Associated with anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA). IgM is often elevated, not IgG.

Acute cholecystitis (Option D): Presents with RUQ tenderness, fever, and leukocytosis. Transaminase elevation is not typically prominent.

choices.text: It rarely occurs in association with cirrhosis.
It frequently produces an elevation of α-fetoprotein
One complication of ulcerative colitis is a significant risk factor for the tumor

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents to his family physician with vague abdominal pain and a sensation of fullness. A CT scan of the abdomen reveals a mass in the right upper quadrant. The patient is scheduled for resection, and a pathologist examining the tumour identifies it as being derived from the bile ducts. Of the following, which is a characteristic of this tumour?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The tumour described is cholangiocarcinoma (bile duct adenocarcinoma).
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is a major risk factor for cholangiocarcinoma.
  • PSC is strongly associated with ulcerative colitis, making ulcerative colitis an indirect risk factor.
  • Other risk factors include liver fluke infections (e.g., Opisthorchis), chronic biliary inflammation, and bile duct anomalies.

Cholangiocarcinoma

  • A malignant tumour of bile duct epithelium, either intrahepatic or extrahepatic (e.g., Klatskin tumours).

Pathogenesis

  • Due to chronic biliary inflammation and stasis.
  • Risk factors:
    • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (linked to ulcerative colitis)
    • Liver fluke infection (Opisthorchis, Clonorchis)
    • Hepatitis B/C, cirrhosis
  • Key mutations: KRAS, IDH1/2, FGFR2

Morphology

  • Infiltrative, firm, white tumours.
  • Gland-like structures in dense fibrous stroma.
  • Intrahepatic: often in non-cirrhotic livers.
  • Extrahepatic: causes obstructive jaundice.

Clinical Features

  • Presents with jaundice, pruritus, and abdominal pain.
  • Often detected late, lymph node spread is common.
  • Poor prognosis despite surgery (5-year survival ~20-40%).

Explanation of other options:

It rarely occurs in association with cirrhosis (Option A): Incorrect. Cholangiocarcinoma can occur in cirrhotic livers, often alongside hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

It has an excellent prognosis (Option B): Incorrect. The prognosis is generally poor due to delayed diagnosis, local invasion, and limited surgical resectability.

It frequently produces an elevation of α-fetoprotein (Option C): Incorrect. α-Fetoprotein (AFP) is typically elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma, not cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant female presents to the emergency room complaining of pain in the upper portion of the right side of her abdomen. Physical examination reveals a fluid wave and hepatomegaly, with her liver palpable 6 cm below the costal margin. Laboratory testing reveals an AST of 213 U/L, ALT of 178 U/L, and alkaline phosphatase of 52 mg/dL. A complete blood count reveals a haemoglobin of 13.4 mg/dL and a platelet count of 224 * 103 cells/μL. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This young pregnant woman presents with RUQ pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites, along with elevated AST and ALT, indicating acute liver congestion or injury.
  • Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state, increasing the risk of hepatic vein the hallmark of Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • The classic triad of abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and ascites in this context makes Budd-Chiari syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

Budd-Chiari Syndrome:

  • A condition caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow, usually due to thrombosis of the major hepatic veins.
  • Leads to liver congestion, hepatomegaly, ascites, and eventually liver failure if untreated.

Risk Factors:

  • Hypercoagulable states: e.g., polycythemia vera, antiphospholipid syndrome, Factor V Leiden.
  • Hormonal causes: Pregnancy, oral contraceptives.
  • Malignancy, especially hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • Idiopathic in some cases.

Pathogenesis:

  • Blockage of hepatic veins → ↑ sinusoidal pressure → centrilobular congestion & necrosis.
  • Results in hepatocyte injury, liver enlargement, and portal hypertension.

Morphology:

  • Gross: Enlarged, red-purple liver with tense capsule.
  • Microscopy: Hemorrhagic congestion, centrilobular necrosis, and sinusoidal dilation.

Clinical Features:

  • Acute: Sudden onset of RUQ pain, ascites, tender hepatomegaly.
  • Chronic: Gradual development of portal hypertension, jaundice, or cirrhosis.
  • If left untreated, it can rapidly lead to liver failure and death.

Explanation of other options:

Portal vein thrombosis (Option A): Causes portal hypertension and splenomegaly, not significant hepatomegaly or elevated AST/ALT.

HELLP syndrome (Option B): Seen in late pregnancy with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets (this patient's platelets are normal).

Acetaminophen toxicity (Option D): Causes massive transaminase elevation (often >1000 U/L), not ascites or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of fever, chills, and abdominal pain. He reports that he has had past episodes of a similar nature, but has not chosen to seek treatment. He has a past medical history of ulcerative colitis and had a colectomy 5 years ago for Stage I colonic adenocarcinoma, which has been in remission. An ERCP reveals strictures in the extrahepatic bile ducts. Of the following, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient presents with recurrent episodes of fever, chills, and abdominal pain, and has a known history of ulcerative colitis, strongly associated with Primary sclerosing cholangitis.
  • ERCP revealing strictures in the extrahepatic bile ducts is a classic diagnostic finding in PSC.

Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis:

  • Definition: PSC is a chronic, progressive, cholestatic liver disease characterised by inflammation and obliterative fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Associations: Strongly associated with ulcerative colitis and other autoimmune conditions. 70% of PSC patients have IBD.
  • Symptoms: Often asymptomatic initially. Later, patients may present with fatigue, pruritus, right upper quadrant pain, cholestasis, and recurrent cholangitis.
  • Diagnosis:
    • MRCP/ERCP shows multifocal strictures and beading.
    • p-ANCA positive in ~65% of cases.
  • Complications: Increased risk of cholangiocarcinoma (10–15%), cirrhosis, and portal hypertension.
  • Prognosis: Progressive disease; may require liver transplant in advanced stages.

Explanation of other options:

Choledocholithiasis (Option A): Causes acute biliary colic and jaundice due to gallstones in the common bile duct, but does not cause chronic strictures or associated with ulcerative colitis.

Metastatic colonic adenocarcinoma (Option B): Unlikely here, given remission and lack of liver masses; it typically affects liver parenchyma, not bile ducts.

Primary biliary cholangitis (Option C): Affects intrahepatic ducts, primarily in middle-aged women; not associated with UC or extrahepatic strictures.

questions.text: A 41-year-old female has been followed by a physician for several years. Originally, she presented to her primary care physician with episodes of itching. Today, she is being seen for fatigue. On physical examination, her physician notes that her conjunctivae are yellow. Other than mild hypothyroidism requiring hormone replacement, she has no other significant past medical history. She has no family history of liver disease. Of the following, what is her most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This middle-aged woman presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice, classic signs of cholestatic liver disease.
  • These features, along with a history of hypothyroidism (another autoimmune disorder), strongly suggest primary biliary cholangitis, a chronic autoimmune destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts.

Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC:

  • Affects mainly middle-aged women.
  • Autoimmune destruction of small intrahepatic bile ducts, leading to cholestasis and eventually cirrhosis.
  • Most patients are positive for antimitochondrial antibodies (AMA).
  • Symptoms:
    • Early: Pruritus, fatigue
    • Late: Jaundice, hyperpigmentation, xanthelasmas
  • Associated with other autoimmune diseases (e.g., Hashimoto thyroiditis).
  • Histology: Florid duct lesions, lymphocytic infiltrates.

Explanation of other options:

α-1-antitrypsin deficiency (Option A): Can cause liver disease and jaundice, but typically presents earlier in life or with emphysema. Pruritus is not a prominent feature.

Galactosemia (Option B): A rare inborn error of metabolism affecting infants, not adults.

Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) (Option C): Also a chronic cholestatic disease, but more common in young men and strongly associated with ulcerative colitis.

choices.text: Mutation analysis of the HFE gene

questions.text: A 42-year-old man has persistently elevated AST and ALT on repeat testing for a month. Workup for viral hepatitis, ceruloplasmin, and SPEP is normal. His serum iron is 201μg/dL, ferritin 289ng/mL, and transferrin saturation 53%. He drinks occasionally and takes no medications. Which of the following would most likely confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has persistently elevated AST and ALT with increased serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation, strongly suggesting hereditary hemochromatosis, an iron overload disorder.
  • The best confirmatory test is HFE gene mutation analysis (commonly C282Y and H63D mutations), which detects the underlying genetic defect causing excess iron absorption.

Explanation of other options:

AAT gene mutation (Option B): For alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, which typically presents with low AAT levels and emphysema or liver disease, does not match this iron profile.

Liver biopsy (Option C): Used to assess iron deposition and hepatic fibrosis, especially if the diagnosis is uncertain or genetic testing is inconclusive. However, it is invasive and not the first-line confirmatory test.

ANCA testing (Option D): Used in autoimmune vasculitis; not relevant in isolated iron overload with elevated transaminases.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male reports that during periods of stress, the whites of his eyes occasionally turn yellow. His vital signs and physical examination are normal. Labs show AST 23 U/L, ALT 19 U/L, ALP 57 U/L, GGT 27 U/L, total bilirubin 2.8 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 0.3 mg/dL, and no bilirubin in urine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This young male presents with episodic scleral icterus (yellowing of the eyes) during stress, which is a classic feature of Gilbert's syndrome.
  • His liver function tests (AST, ALT, ALP, GGT) are normal, but his total bilirubin is elevated, with predominantly unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (total 2.8 mg/dL, direct 0.3 mg/dL).
  • It is a benign hereditary condition due to reduced activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UGT1A1).
  • Leads to impaired conjugation of bilirubin → buildup of unconjugated bilirubin.
  • Triggered by stress, fasting, illness, or exertion.
  • No bilirubin in urine since unconjugated bilirubin is water-insoluble.
  • Normal liver enzymes and an otherwise healthy patient support a non-pathologic cause.

Explanation of other options:

Crigler-Najjar Syndrome (Option B): Type I: Severe, presents in infancy with very high unconjugated bilirubin (>20 mg/dL), can cause kernicterus. Type II: Less severe, but still has bilirubin levels higher than in Gilbert's. Patient here is asymptomatic with only mild elevation, making Crigler-Najjar unlikely

Dubin-Johnson Syndrome (Option C): Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to MRP2 transporter defect. Associated with dark liver pigmentation and bilirubinuria. Inconsistent with this case: no elevated direct bilirubin, no bilirubin in urine

Rotor Syndrome (Option D): Also causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. No liver pigmentation, but bilirubin in urine is present. Again, not a match for this patient's labs

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presents with anorexia, fatigue, nausea, pruritus, icterus, and occasional abdominal pain. Liver function tests show AST 350 U/L, ALT 400 U/L, and serum bilirubin 3.1 mg/dL. Antimitochondrial antibody (AMA) is positive. Liver biopsy findings are shown below. Which of the following is not a typical histologic feature of the suspected disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Periductal fibrosis (onion-skin pattern) is characteristic of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC), not PBC.
  • In PBC, fibrosis is portal-based, not concentric around ducts.
  • Positive AMA, especially against PDC-E2, is highly specific for Primary Biliary Cholangitis.
  • A middle-aged woman with pruritus, fatigue, and a cholestatic pattern of liver enzymes supports the diagnosis.
  • Liver biopsy shows features of small bile duct injury typical of PBC.

Histological Features of Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC):

  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltration of portal tracts is a hallmark feature. (Option A ruled out)
  • Florid duct lesion: Granulomatous destruction of small intrahepatic bile ducts. (Option D ruled out)
  • Feathery degeneration of periportal hepatocytes due to bile salt accumulation. (Option C ruled out)
  • It may also show Mallory-Denk bodies in hepatocytes.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man has had progressive fatigue, pruritus, and icterus for 3 months. On physical examination, he now has generalised jaundice. The abdomen is not distended; on palpation, there is no abdominal pain, and there are no masses. Laboratory studies show a serum alkaline phosphatase level of 285 U/L, AST 350 U/L, and ALT 400 U/L, while S. bilirubin is 3.1 mg/dL. After cholangiography, liver biopsy was performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Periductal 'onion-skin' fibrosis is the key histological feature of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC).
  • Typically affects middle-aged men, and is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease (though not necessary for diagnosis).
  • Presents with a cholestatic pattern (elevated ALP) and progressive liver dysfunction.

Histological Features of PSC:

  • Periductal 'onion-skin' fibrosis:
    • Concentric layers of fibrosis surrounding the bile ducts, resembling an onion-skin appearance
    • Leads to ductal narrowing, atrophy, and eventual obliteration (termed 'tombstone scar')
  • Bile duct injury:
    • Degeneration and loss of bile ducts over time
    • Chronic inflammation is often present around the ducts
  • Cholestasis and bile plugs:
    • Accumulation of bile due to duct obstruction
  • Progressive fibrosis and cirrhosis:
    • Irregular bridging fibrosis develops between the portal tracts

Explanation of other options:

Primary biliary cirrhosis (Option A): Shows florid duct lesions and is associated with anti-mitochondrial antibodies, mainly affecting middle-aged women.

Autoimmune hepatitis (Option C): Presents with markedly elevated AST/ALT, positive ANA or anti-SMA, and interface hepatitis, but does not show periductal fibrosis.

Von Meyenburg complex (Option D): Benign developmental anomaly, showing disorganised small bile ducts, not associated with jaundice or pruritus.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male patient presented with increasing anorexia, loss of appetite and easy fatigability. Physical examination shows hepatomegaly, and lab findings show raised bilirubin (2.6 mg/dL). Radiologic investigation showed a mass lesion in the liver, which shows hyperenhancement during the arterial phase and washout in the venous phase. To know the nature of the mass, a biopsy was performed, the image of which is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classic imaging pattern of arterial phase hyperenhancement followed by venous washout is highly characteristic of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
  • This is due to the tumour's arterial blood supply, contrasting with normal liver parenchyma, which is enhanced later via the portal system.
  • Histopathology confirms this
    • Increased plate/trabecular thickness of hepatocytes.
    • Loss of normal portal tract architecture.
    • Atypical cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and sometimes bile production.

Histological Features of HCC:

  • Thickened hepatocyte plates (trabeculae): Normally 1-2 cells thick; in HCC, often >3 cells thick.
  • Loss of normal lobular architecture: No normal portal triads or central veins.
  • Tumour cells resemble hepatocytes but with nuclear atypia, hyperchromasia, and increased nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio.
  • Pseudoacinar structures may be seen.
  • Bile production and Mallory hyaline may be present.
  • Vascular invasion is common, especially into hepatic and portal veins.

Explanation of other options:

Cirrhosis (Option A): While cirrhosis is a risk factor for HCC, it does not present as a solitary hypervascular mass. Biopsy shows fibrous septa and regenerative nodules, not thickened plates or tumour cells.

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option B): Typically shows delayed enhancement, not arterial phase enhancement with washout. Also, more glandular histology is seen, not trabecular.

Hepatic adenoma (Option D): Benign lesion, often seen in young women on oral contraceptives. Radiologically lacks venous washout, and histology shows bland hepatocytes without architectural disruption or vascular invasion.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient complains of on-and-off abdominal pain. On proper evaluation and on ultrasound examination, a benign hepatic lesion was identified. To safeguard, and on patient request, a partial hepatectomy was performed and sent for histopathological examination (image of which is shown below). Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The biopsy shows dilated, blood-filled vascular spaces lined by flattened endothelium and separated by thin fibrous septa, which are classic for cavernous hemangioma.
  • It is the most common benign liver tumour, often an incidental finding on imaging or histopathology.

Cavernous Hemangioma

  • Composed of large, dilated vascular channels with a flattened endothelial lining.
  • Separated by scant connective tissue stroma.
  • Typically subcapsular and well-circumscribed.
  • No risk of malignant transformation.
  • Often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatic Adenoma (Option A): Composed of benign hepatocytes arranged in 1-2 cell-thick plates. Lacks normal portal tracts. It can have prominent arteries and haemorrhage. Associated with oral contraceptives, anabolic steroids.

Capillary Hemangioma (Option C): Much less common in the liver. Composed of thin-walled capillaries with plump endothelial cells in a lobular pattern. Histology lacks the large, cavernous spaces seen in cavernous hemangioma.

Peliosis Hepatis (Option D): Characterised by blood-filled cystic spaces that lack an endothelial lining. Seen in association with chronic illness, anabolic steroids, TB, or HIV. Not a true vascular tumor-represents a vascular abnormality or sinusoidal dilation.

questions.text: A 2-year-old male child presents with loss of appetite and on-and-off vomiting. USG of the abdomen shows a space-occupying lesion in the liver, which is hyperechoic relative to the adjacent liver, although hypoechoic fibrotic septa are also seen. Partial hepatectomy was performed and sent for histopathological examination (Image shows below). Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child is 2 years old, which strongly favours hepatoblastoma, the most common liver tumour in early childhood.
  • Imaging features (hyperechoic lesion with hypoechoic fibrotic septa) are consistent with this diagnosis.
  • Histopathology shows sheets of small, round to polygonal cells, often mimicking fetal or embryonal hepatocytes, which is typical for the epithelial subtype of hepatoblastoma.

Concise Explanation of Hepatoblastoma (from Robbins):

  • The most common primary liver tumour in children <3 years.
  • Two main histologic types:
    • Epithelial: resembles developing liver, fetal or embryonal cells.
    • Mixed epithelial and mesenchymal: contains bone, cartilage, or muscle.
  • Often linked to APC gene mutations (e.g., FAP).
  • Presents as an abdominal mass, vomiting, or signs of liver dysfunction.
  • Good prognosis with surgery + chemotherapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Cavernous Hemangioma (Option A): Most common benign liver tumour, but in adults, not children. Histology: Dilated, thin-walled blood-filled vascular spaces lined by flattened endothelial cells. Usually an incidental finding, not associated with fibrotic septa.

Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) (Option C): Rare in children; typically affects adults with cirrhosis or chronic liver disease. Histology: Thickened hepatic plates, trabecular growth, loss of normal lobular architecture. Radiology: Arterial phase enhancement + venous washout (not typical in this case).

Cholangiocarcinoma (Option D): Adenocarcinoma of bile duct origin; rare in children. Histology: Gland-forming malignant cells with fibrotic (desmoplastic) stroma. Seen in older adults, associated with PSC or liver flukes.

choices.text: It is more common in young adults, rarely older than 40 years old.
It is usually associated with cirrhosis.
It has a better prognosis compared with other types of hepatocellular carcinoma.
Characteristic tumor cells are large with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm separated by thick bands of hyalinized collagen

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a mass in the left lobe of the liver underwent lobectomy. The left lobe was sent for histopathological examination, the image of which is shown below. All statements about this lesion are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The described histological features are characteristic of the fibrolamellar variant of hepatocellular carcinoma (FL-HCC).
  • FL-HCC is distinct from conventional HCC:
    • It typically affects young adults, often <40 years old.
    • It arises in non-cirrhotic livers.
    • Serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels are usually normal or only mildly elevated.
    • It has a better prognosis compared to conventional HCC.
  • So, option B is incorrect because fibrolamellar HCC is not associated with cirrhosis, unlike classic HCC.

Explanation of Other Options:

It is more common in young adults, rarely older than 40 years old (Option A): True. FL-HCC typically affects patients aged 10-40 years.

It has a better prognosis compared with other types of hepatocellular carcinoma (Option C): True. Compared to conventional HCC, FL-HCC generally has a better prognosis, especially in the absence of cirrhosis.

Characteristic tumour cells are large with eosinophilic granular cytoplasm separated by thick bands of hyalinized collagen(Option D): True. This is the histologic hallmark of fibrolamellar HCC.
